Award.AwardTitle: Integrating and Extending Decisions from Experience Phenomena with Instance-Based Learning Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the Principal Investigator (PI) will study decision making phenomena that emerge from situations in which the explicit description of outcomes and probabilities is not available (i.e., Decisions from Experience, DFE). The PI will determine how Prospect Theory and other models of choice under risk may or may not account for human behavior in DFE situations. The PI will also examine the ability of an Instance-Based Learning model ( IBL) derived from the ACT-R theory of cognition (Anderson & Lebiere, 1998) to account for behavior in DFE. The performance of this model will also be examined in two new domains: First by considering decisions from experience in dynamic environments, and second by investigating the effects of decisions from experience in situations involving more than one person.
In terms of broader impacts, this research will expand our knowledge of human behavior in the naturalistic situations in which we use our experience to make decisions. The research investigates situations where people have the opportunity to sample options before making decisions for real and also situations where they are forced to make consequential decisions without exploring the options. These types of situations arise frequently in Engineering, Business, and Medicine. The research will also result in concrete experimental tools and computational models to be made available to the academic and research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Often, when making daily life decisions, we do not count with an explicit description of the possible outcomes from the potential options or with the explicit statement of the probabilities of those outcomes. For example, while driving and selecting possible routes, we mostly act on the options and adapt to the results observed from our actions; we make decisions from experience (i.e., Decisions from Experience, DFE).

Theories that explain human decision making have traditionally involved principles and developments from Economics and Psychology, using monetary gambles (i.e., "prospects") that explicitly state outcomes and associated probabilities. These theories that explain decisions from description, are able to detect deviations from rational behavior (biases) but are unable to explain how we make decisions from experience. This project has contributed to our understanding and formalization of decision making processes that involved in experiential decisions. We have accomplished two major goals: 1- to demonstrate that it is possible to explain many phenomena of DFE with a single model derived from Instance-Based Learning Theory (IBLT, Gonzalez, Lerch, Lebiere, 2003); and 2- to extend the current knowledge of DFE in two dimensions: from repeated choice behavior in static and binary-choice environments to repeated choice in dynamic, complex, and naturalistic environments; and from repeated choice at the individual level to repeated choice in small groups.

In a total of 16 publications in highly ranked journals, this project integrated the knowledge of many models that have emerged to generate general conclusions regarding the models predictions and generalization abilities to many variations of DFE situations. We showed how one model demonstrates robustness across multiple DFE paradigms. Based on IBLT (Gonzalez, Lerch, & Lebiere, 2003) and cognitive principles proposed by the ACT-R theory of cognition (Anderson & Lebiere, 1998), an IBL model can account for currently known behavioral phenomena in DFE and novel phenomena in dynamic environments in individuals as well as in situations involving more than one person. We demonstrated the robustness and boundaries of IBLT in various experiments that tested decision biases in experiential experimental paradigms. We discovered that traditional biases of decisions from description disappear when choices are made from experience. Furthermore, IBLT helped to explain how these biases emerge and disappear according to the frequency and recency of events in the available choice options, and the possibilities that a human has to explore these options. We demonstrated the effects of the amount of exploration, the structure of the environment, and opportunities to experience the frequency and recency of outcomes. IBLT was able to explain all the phenomena with an integrated model. Importantly, we also advanced phenomena in DFE by changing traditional experiential paradigms into paradigms that involved more complex and dynamic environments. We investigated DFE in dynamic environments and in situations involving pairs of participants (2x2 games).

Finally, we expanded our modeling infrastructure to be able to generate models of multiple agents and with any choice problems including many options, beyond binary choice. This library is available online, free to download to use by any researchers (http://www.hss.cmuur.edu/departments/sds/ddmlab/downloads.html#pyibl). We also generated new R libraries which are available for general use (http://www.hss.cmu.edu/departments/sds/ddmlab/downloads.html#r-ibl). These new libraries allow researchers to generate IBL models with multiple agents, more than two options, and any option attributes.
